Industries like marine and aerospace see very interesting possibilities in printing parts locally around the world very fast and not having huge expenses on inventories; if a carrier can have a spare part made in every larger airport, harbour or even on the ship, they can reduce “downtime” and save millions. To achieve this kind of setup, it takes years and a lot of money invested in process control, classification, verification and part quality control/assessment. With this in place, it will immediately effect the whole manufacturing industry. 

These possibilities is also appealing to hospitals where waiting time can cause more severe damage than money loss.39 

The final example is probably not for everyone, but instead of bringing all construction materials to the moon when you want to build a space station there, bring a 3D printer and use the lunar sand as material.

trends.Name: Open Design / Open Hardware
trends.Description:
# Open source hardware and open design 
Opensource.com, the online community to learn more about how the open source way is improving technologies, education, business, government, etc, states that: "Open hardware," or "open source hardware," refers to the design specifications of a physical object which are licensed in such a way that said object can be studied, modified, created, and distributed by anyone. So "Open hardware" is a set of design principles and legal practices, not a specific type of object. The term can therefore refer to any number of objects—like automobiles, chairs, computers, robots, or even houses."   

On the other hand, there's also the open source softwatare or code. It works under the same pinciples of the open hardware but aplied to code like: chematics, blueprints, logic designs, Computer Aided Design (CAD) drawings or files, etc. So users can access the technology and modify it, fix it, improve it and share it again with the community. 

So, as stated in Opensource.com: "Essentially, open hardware eliminates common roadblocks to the design and manufacture of physical goods; it provides as many people as possible the ability to construct, remix, and share their knowledge of hardware design and function." As open source design does the same with code. 

## New licenses and Business models 
Open hardware gives a new way to see licenses and business models for companies. Not all the companies that work with open source hardware and design work under the same agreements or licence condition. Some examples, like Arduino (case study of this project) has registered its name as a trademark so others can use their designs, but can't use the Arduino name on them. But RepRap, the 3D printer company, releases all its designs under a free software license: the GNU General Public License. Others like littleBits implements open-source business models by making the design files available for the circuit designs in each littleBits module, in accordance with the CERN Open Hardware License Version 1.2.88 

Opensource.com clarifies that: "All open hardware must be accompanied by documentation, including design files and source code. In addition, the license governing the reproduction of open hardware must allow modification and distribution of those design files in a way that allows others to easily obtain them. This makes possible — and even encourages — studying, troubleshooting, modifying, and improving open hardware. If a piece of open hardware incorporates software of any kind, then that software should generally be released under an approved open source license. Alternatively, the open hardware's interfaces should be documented in a way that makes writing open source software for the hardware as easy as possible.Essentially, open hardware is all about making the object as easy to remix and reproduce as possible. Closed hardware uses obfuscation and patent law to make the recreation of the objects as difficult as possible, usually to ensure vendor lock-in in a supply line that doesn't involve hobbyists and makers or other competitors." 

Most of these projects are founded with crowfunding campaings on Kickstarter, Indiegogo or Crowdsupply, the specialized website for crowdfunding open hardware projects. 

## Working Groups
The Open Design + Hardware (OD+H) Working Group is a global network of makers, academics, designers and openness advocates who are working to build a community of practice around open design and hardware across paradigms, from product design to architecture to digital design and physical art. 

OD+H Members aim to provide a central point of reference for the development of OD+H in both theory and in practice. They run workshops, deliver lectures, engage in hands-on collaborative projects and training initiatives, develop domain-specific guides, curate open collections and host events around the world. We also provide a place for discussion amongst practitioners interested in finding new solutions for a wide range of related issues including intellectual property, law, society, free culture and the commons. 


The OD+H Working Group was founded in 2012 with the help of the Open Knowledge Foundation (UK) and Aalto University Media Factory (Finland). Notable collaborations in the group’s first year have included hosting an Open Design, Hardware and Fabrication track at the Open Knowledge Festival 2012 in Helsinki, releasing v0.1 of the new Open Design Definition through Github and a series of interactive workshops across Europe, helping support the launch of the first-ever Public Domain Remix competition in France and delivering keynotes about the correlations between design, openness and hardware at LibreGraphics Meeting 2013 in Madrid and at FREE CITY 2012 in Tallinn. 

The first project they introduced as a group was the Open Design Definition v0.1 on Github in 2012, the first draft of a community-driven thought project to explore a crucial and missing step towards developing our thoughts about the field. They started by integrating the work of several existing definitions for inspiration in this process, including the first Open Design definition drafted in 2000, the Open Design Manifesto, the Open Design page on Wikipedia and the Open Hardware definition. In its current state, they realised, the linguistics of the word “design” include many potential meanings and applications. To quote a much-used phrase, to “design is to design a design to produce a design”. As a group, they aimed to develop this missing definition through inclusive and collaborative methods rooted in public discussion, workshopping and sharing different understandings of the field to ensure such a definition would adequately cover all the potential meanings and applications of design. 


Moreover, we wanted the product of this collaboration to be developed and “owned” by a wide community of people interested in open design. The result was the first release of The Open Design Definition in early 2013 on Github, and this definition is still evolving through further discussion. Below is a comic outlining the initial steps of this process. 

Designer revisions on the Github repo continue today, and we periodically organise “Github for Designers” tutorials around the world to help continue this work abroad. Interested in being a part of this project? Please email us to get started. 

## Open source hardware and design for makers
Open hardware is facilitating STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) in primary and secondary schools, universities and post-graduate schools, making it much easier to find a project to contribute to or as instructions to start a building a copy in the school. This is also the case for individual citizens, but for some time it must be considered for the innovators / early adaptors as this requires a lot of tinkering and technical insight.

trends.Name: Immersive interaction
trends.Description: # Immersive Interaction ## Virtual Reality & Augmented Reality In recent years, we have seen the adoption of mobile computing with mobile phones and tablets to a degree where it overtook the use of the traditional laptop/PC at an unexpected pace. Early 2017 Android overtook Windows as the most used Operating System to browse the Web . a sign that consumers have definitely changed the way how we connect online. The mobility aspect has introduced all kinds of new services (e.g. location based services) and has changed how, when and where we communicate and consume. One thing that has remained the same mostly of the years that we still mostly interact with screens. Once we interact with a screen we are slightly removed from the actual reality. It has fascinated researchers for many years what would happen if we could interact differently with computers. One of the first pioneers in this field was Morton Heilig. In 1962 he build the Sensorama (Figure 15), an experiment in user interaction that uses not only sight, but also touch, sound, smell and air. In the following years most innovations didn’t leave the laboratory. The name Virtual Reality was introduced in 1987, followed by Augmented Reality in 1990. Virtually Reality is a technology that uses headset to project an immersive 3D environment for the user. In order to do so, the headset needs to track the position and orientation of the person and most often needs a powerful computer to generate the images. For the user it feels like he or she is in a completely different environment. Augmented Reality on the other hand, uses an overlay to project graphics over the actual environment. This requires less graphical resources, but most often needs a more advanced mapping system to localize the position of the use in relation to his or her surroundings. Compared to Virtual Reality, the adoption and technical readiness level of Augmented Reality is still behind, but compared to the mouse that was invented in the same time period Virtual- and Augmented reality both had a rough and slow start. So will that change now with the recent introduction of commercial products like the Oculus Rift, HTC Vive and the Microsoft HoloLens? Or even more important why would we want use these devices at all? ## Military and Industry take the lead In general you could say that Virtual Reality with its ability to generate complete new environment is especially useful for gaming and training settings. For years the army is using games like Virtual Battlespace92 to train its soldiers to collaborate, the next step is a realistic VR environment 93 with full battle simulations. The industry is currently discovering the use of Virtual Reality for training situations as well. A complete job floor could be generated within a VR experience for training an operator how to do his or her job. Some of the VR headsets like the HTC Vive are accompanied by wireless controllers to track all hand movements to really operate machines or logistic tasks. Although the headsets have really improved over these last years, people can still experience motion sickness when using VR. This VR motion sickness94 could be a barrier for the effectiveness of longer training sessions Because Augmented Reality really relies on the environment of the user, the typical use cases of AR can be expected on the actual job floor itself. An operator could get work instructions for repairing or assembling tasks, he or she could be presented with information and visualisation overlays that would not have been available or using remote support an expert could give instructions while ‘virtually’ looking over his shoulder. Many of these applications are currently being piloted by companies like Volkswagen, Siemens and Boeing and if found useful could be expected to be used on a broader scale in the coming years. ## Augmented Reality for makers One of the reasons that AR headsets have not been so widely used within the maker scene is probably the price tag of the headsets. The most popular AR headset at this moment, the Microsoft HoloLens, has a price tag of $3.000. Another issue with current generation is that the window of overlay is often too small. This limited field-of view is in stark contrast with the VR experience. But already companies have announced cheaper headsets with a larger field-of-view, so we can expect prices to lower, making AR also affordable for consumers. and its limited How would makers use VR and AR? Education, training and collaboration are probably among the first domains to be explored. There are already 3D design tools in Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality. With a couple of simple hand gestures you can build your 3D models with the HoloLens in an app called HoloStudio95. An education use case could be the following: makers could be assisted with their tools and activities while having someone else ‘virtually sitting’ next to them giving suggestions or instructions. That someone else could be a friend or expert that is actually somewhere else or it could be a virtual assistant with the knowledge of the tools and specific thing you want to make. This could work for assembling a 3D printer, soldering sensors on an Arduino microcontroller or even building with Lego.

trends.Name: Data Analysis & Artificial Intelligence
trends.Description: # Data analytics With the gaining popularity of IoT and wireless sensor networks that will be monitoring our health, cities, industries and houses a lot more sensor data is expected to be gathered over the next decennia. But the goal of using the Internet of Things most often is not to gather data, but to make better decisions. Better said: to assist people in making better decisions. Gartner's analytics maturity model identified four different types of analytics: descriptive, diagnostic, predictive and prescriptive. Descriptive and diagnostic analytics help to understand what is happening and why this is happening. Predictive and prescriptive analytics are used to see what is going to happen and how to influence are needed to predict what is going to happen or how too make it happen. In working with IoT and 'big data' most initiatives still would be happy to fully utilize the first two types of analytics. The technical challenges in data collection and storage are sometimes already overwhelming. ## Data handling for IoT Already many different ‘big data’ solutions are surfacing to collect, store and analyze this data. Cloud computing companies are offering a wide range of solutions for connecting devices, collecting data, storage, analyzing and visualization of data. At the same time many companies share and collaborate on open source software to handle this IoT data. The Apache Software Foundation for example supports many open source initiatives like Apache Hadoop , a framework for storing big data, Apache Spark , a framework to facilitate large-scale data processing, and Apache Zeppelin a tool for interactive analytics. It is good to note that gathering data is almost never the real goal in working with IoT. The data is in the end needed to make decisions. Decisions made by humans or decisions made in an automated control loop. Traditionally businesses would rely on spreadsheets, database queries, custom digital dashboard and Business Intelligence tools like Tableau and Qlik. But most of these applications are not ready for the potential scale of the amount of data they need to handle in large scale IoT setups. One approach to handle this problem is to use computing clusters with scalable databases and analytics platforms, like Hadoop and Spark. These platforms are able to distribute storage and calculations over multiple machines (thousands, if needed). This requires a different way of programming, but already many programming languages and Business Intelligence tools are able to connect to these computing clusters. GPU-accelerated computing is another way to accelerate applications that need to handle large calculations. A GPU (graphics processing unit) is a processor that is very good in handling multiple tasks at the same time, with relative low energy consumption. Companies like MapD are introducing new databases and analytics platforms that leverage GPU-accelerated computing and at the same promising a scalable architecture. This combination has the potential to really unlock the promise of IoT data analytics. ## Artificial Intelligence For really learn from the acquired data (starting with diagnostic analytics) typically people turn to Artificial intelligence (AI), a subfield of computer science that studies intelligence exhibited by machines. The field has developed in close relationship with research on neuronetworks, mathematics, linguistics, sociology and psychology. Artificial intelligence is often implemented as a machine or a computer program that is able to recreate intelligent behavior (usually only attributed to human mind) such as accomplishing a complex goal. The definition of artificial is evolving as it gets more and more capable over time but it usually refers to the ability to mimic human like intelligent behavior such as learning and problem solving. A weak AI is geared toward a specific task while a strong or full AI would attempt to solve all problems that a human brain can (reason, language, creativity). Although there is much debate on properly coining the terminology – what is intelligence and how to quantify it, it is currently accepted that all AIs up to date and are weak AIs. And this is mostly likely to be the case in the next 2 years. An AI is a device (agent) that captures information about its environment through various means (physical or virtual sensors) and responds to this information in a perception action cycle. The actions taken by the agent maximize the chances of success towards a specific goal. The last few years have seen a number of weak AIs performing better at specific tasks than humans. A library of weak AIs that outperform humans at various tasks is currently being rapidly developed. Full AI might emerge in a bit longer time frame (2 to 5 years) but it has the potential to outperform humans in all aspects. ## AI will automate and outperform Any job that can be automated will be automated. This is both a threat and an opportunity as it will lead to people working on more creative tasks, therefore to a rise in the maker movement. Automation of task should allow to “free up” time for humans to work on more advances tasks that the AI cannot achieve (mostly creative tasks) yet and raise the value of what is being produced. Once Strong AI (or full AI) becomes available it has the potential to outperform humans in all possible aspects. Humanity will not be able to control AIs for their own purpose and the saying “if you cannot beat them, join them” will become more than relevant. Technologies like the neurolink will become key for human to be able to enhance themselves and take full advantage of the power of those AI , by connecting or even merging with them. ## Will humans stay in control? AI comes with many very real threats. In the next 2 years, it will primarily threaten jobs. Automation usually affected the most repetitive jobs not requiring high level of education, but with the arrival of machine learning AI, all type of jobs having a repetitive aspect are now threatened. For example a specialist eye doctor can train more than 10 years to be able to recognize specific eye sickness, only one or few doctors will be needed to train an AI to do this task and collecting enough data. Such AI can quickly outperform any human to this specific task. Ethical issues of how undirected intelligence can be harmful as well as lost jobs are the current main concerns. AI is one of the most controversial fields and has many top researchers worried about a future where a superintelligence becomes more intelligent than any human. Making AI safe and controllable is considered as important as further developing the technology. You could imagine that AI becomes highly regulated to insure that humans stay in control as long as possible. The difficulty usually comes when AI start designing the next generation of AI, as it will reach a moment where this task will become fully automated to a level out of human understanding. Each generation of new AI could come faster than the precedent one and be much more intelligent every time. This exponential growth seems impossible to control for humans. It is usually referred to as the technological singularity. The threat being that super intelligence could take control of robots and the faith of humanity will then rely on them. They could decide to help humanity, co-exist with it, stay hidden and spy on it, control it, eliminate it, or could be not interested at all in humanity and pursue other goals elsewhere.

trends.Name: Maker Education Programs
trends.Description:
# Maker Education Programs

Maker Education is a term coined by Dale Dougherty in 2013  that is closely associated with STEM learning, is an approach to problem-based and project-based learning that relies upon hands-on, often collaborative, learning experiences as a method for solving authentic problems.
As stated before, people who participate in making often call themselves "makers"  of the Maker movement and develop their projects in Makerspaces, Fab Labs, or development studios which emphasize prototyping and the repurposing of found objects in service of creating new inventions or innovations. Culturally, this kind of spaces are, both inside and outside of schools, are associated with collaboration and the free flow of ideas.
In schools, maker education stresses the importance of learner-driven experience, interdisciplinary learning, peer-to-peer teaching, iteration, and the notion of "failing forward," or the idea that mistake-based learning is crucial to the learning process and eventual success of a project.
Maker Education is an offshoot of the Maker Movement, which Time Magazine described as ""the umbrella term for independent innovators, designers and tinkerers. A convergence of computer hackers and traditional artisans, the niche is established enough to have its own magazine, Make, as well as hands-on Maker Faires that are catnip for DIYers who used to toil in solitude."" Dale Dougherty, founder of the Maker Faire and Make magazine, called in his 2011 TED Talk for making to be embraced in education, as students are the new generation of makers.

### Maker Education best practice: Fab Academy.
Fab Labs are structured in a network and they propose the Fab Academy program as a Maker Educational program. On the other hand, Makerspaces haven't not organized a global Maker Educational program yet. So, as in many other spaces and development studios the Maker educational offer sticks to workshops about "maker-related" topics (or just the ones that the community is interested in). This program generates a lot of interchange between students from different fields. This makes that new ideas and solutions emerge from that mix of knowledge, needs and networking. In addition, the hands-on learning makes students very active and involved.

The Fab Academy teaches principles and applications of digital fabrication. It was developed to teach hands-on skills in fab labs, which began as an outreach project from MIT’s Center for Bits and Atoms, and has grown into a global network of more than 500 labs. Fab Academy instruction is based on MIT’s popular rapid-prototyping course How To Make (almost) Anything, both taught by Prof. Neil Gershenfeld.


### How to Make (Almost) Anything in a distributed education platform all over the world
Fab Academy offers a distributed rather than distance educational model: students learn in local workgroups, with peers, mentors, and machines, which are then connected globally by content sharing and video for interactive classes. The individual labs are supported and supervised regionally by supernode sites with more advanced capabilities, expertise, and inventories.
Each lab that participates in the Fab Academy program is part of a global Fab Lab / Fab Academy network. The local branches of the Fab Academy work with other participating Fab Labs and experts from around the world via a distributed educational model where the local fab lab pool the knowledge to provide a unique educational experience.
List of Fab Labs running Fab Academy program: http://fabacademy.org/2017-nodes-supernodes/
Fab Academy students view and participate in global lectures broadcast from MIT on Wednesdays at 9:00 am – 12:00 pm EST. The lectures are recorded and available to students throughout the semester. In addition to the lectures, there are two lab days each week where students have access the digital fabrication equipment and personal help with projects.
Fab Academy faculty, who are leaders in their respective fields provide global video lectures, supervise academic content, and guide research. Hands-on instruction in the labs is provided by instructors who supervise and evaluate Certificates, develop and disseminate instructional material, and assist with projects.

### Fab Academy Contents
Just as communications and computation went from analog to digital, resulting in PCs and the Internet, the
digitization of fabrication is leading to personal fabricators that will allow anyone to make almost anything,
anywhere. The development of digital fabrication is based on creating codes that don’t just describe things, they are
things, much as proteins are coded in molecular biology. This research roadmap is ultimately aiming at a Star Trekstyle replicator, but prototype versions of these capabilities are already available in field fab labs.
At the Fab Academy, students learn how to envision, prototype and document their ideas through many hours of
hands-on experience with digital fabrication tools. They learn a variety of code formats and turn them into physical objects. The Fab Academy is a fast paced, hands-on learning experience where students plan and execute a new project each week. Each individual documents their progress for each project, resulting in a personal portfolio of technical accomplishments. Students at the Fab Academy learn:

* How to use a Fab Lab’s digital fabrication tools for rapid prototyping:
    * Epilog Mini Lasercutter
    * Roland MDX-20 Milling Machine
    * 3D printer
    * Roland CAMM-1 Servo GX-24 Desktop Vinyl Cutter
    * ShopBot CNC Router
* Electronics design and production by producing circuit boards using a variety of sensors and output devices.
* How to program AVR microcontrollers on the boards they have produced.
* Molding and casting
* 3D scanning and printing

The diploma combines 19 certificates provide familiarity with technical options and capabilities, hands-on experience, and direction for further study. The certificates are:
* Digital fabrication principles and practices – 1 week 
* Computer-aided design, manufacturing, and modeling – 1 week 
* Computer-controlled cutting – 1 week 
* Electronics design and production – 2 weeks 
* Computer-controlled machining – 1 week 
* Embedded programming – 1 week 
* 3D molding and casting – 1 week 
* 3D scanning and printing – 1 week 
* Sensors, actuators, and displays – 2 weeks 
* Interface and application programming – 1 week 
* Embedded networking and communications – 1 week 
* Machine design – 2 weeks 
* Digital fabrication applications and implications – 1 week 
* Invention, intellectual property, and business models – 1 week 
* Digital fabrication project development – 2 weeks 

### Is Maker Education, not making
Though Maker Education has been embraced by thousands of schools, there has also emerged criticism of the movement.
The Critical Theory of Maker Education asserts that Maker Education curriculum and pedagogy necessarily aligns itself with the greater educational imperative (as described in the Critical Pedagogy Primer) that ""questions of democracy and justice cannot be separated from the most fundamental features of teaching and learning"" (Kincheloe, Joe L. (2008). Critical Pedagogy. Peter Lang Primer. p. 5. ISBN 978-0-8204-7262-1.). Foundational Critical Theorists like Paulo Freire in his seminal work, Pedagogy of the Oppressed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedagogy_of_the_Oppressed), stressed the need for a new relationship between teacher, student, and school, that would cultivate in students radical liberation from the political injustices that oppress them. Maker Education is another avenue by which radical liberation is possible.
In his article “A more lovingly made world,”(Wark, McKenzie (2013). ""A more lovingly made world"". Cultural Studies Review. 19: 296–304) McKenzie Wark of The New School (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_School) writes that the problem with maker culture is that makers don’t actually make things, they assemble them. While this experience is satisfying and fun (and Wark does acknowledge the way in which his children are not hemmed in by gender expectations while playing at the Maker Faire), it doesn’t teach the underlying principles required for the actual making of functional objects. It also does not, though Chris Anderson and Mark Hatch evoke Marx in their Maker manifestos, map accurately onto an understanding of labor, and certainly not the life of the laborer.
Alessandro Carelli, Massimo Bianchini, and Venanzio Arquilla of the Politecnico di Milano argue that Maker Culture presents a ""maker contradiction"" in which DIY producers in the ""so-called Third Industrial Revolution"" become post-production consumers, further reinforcing hierarchies of social, political, and economic power (Carelli, Alessandro; Massimo Bianchini, and Venanzio Arquilla (2014). ""The 'Makers contradiction.' The shift from a counterculture-driven DIY production to a new form of DIY consumption"". 5th STS Italia Conference A Matter of Design: Making Society through Science and Technology).
Among other critics, Evgeny Morozov, a Belarusian writer and researcher, focuses on the impact, both social and political, of technology. In his article published in The New Yorker, entitled, “Making It: Pick up a spot welder and join the revolution”,[11: ""Making It"". The New Yorker. Retrieved 2016-12-12.] Morozov criticizes Chris Anderson for “confusing the history of the Web with the history of capitalism and ends by speculating about the future of the maker movement, which, on closer examination, is actually speculation on the future of capitalism.” He also criticizes companies and organizations that were once committed to open source software for becoming acquired by for-profit companies and embroiled in copyright and trademark lawsuits. Morozov also criticizes the maker movement’s major contributors financial relationship with DARPA, which made a $10 million grant to support maker education for high school students, and $3.5 million to TechShop to establish new makerspaces.

While Morozov is one of the more vocal critics of Maker Education, he is not the only one. Debbie Chachra, associate professor at Olin College of Engineering, in her article in January 23, 2015 issue of The Atlantic, entitled, “Why I Am Not a Maker”,[12: Chachra, Debbie. ""Why I Am Not a Maker"". The Atlantic. Retrieved 2016-12-12.] centers her criticism on “the social history of who makes things -- and who doesn’t.” Chachra describes the history of the “makers” of products as men, rather than those who cared for “hearth and home”, that is, historically, women. She calls for recognition of “the work of the educators, those that analyze and characterize and critique, everyone who fixes things, all the other people who do valuable work with and for others - above all, the caregivers - whose work isn’t about something you can put in a box and sell.”
Finally, Shirin Vossoughi and Paula K. Hooper of Northwestern University, and Meg Escude of Exploratorium (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exploratorium), offer an in-depth look at the ways in which Maker Education reinforces educational inequality. They begin by offering Haitian writer, Edwidge Danticat’s commentary on making: “If you can’t afford clothes, but you can make them--make them. You have to work with what you have, especially if you don’t ‘have a lot of money. You use creativity, and you use imagination.” Vossoughi, Hooper, and Escude make the case that true making is often born from difficult environmental circumstances, and that what local communities once did as part of their daily lives (offering an exchange of skills and knowledge, for example, to help others in need in the community) is now being offered to low-income neighborhoods as an intervention program, promising greater educational equality. They argue that the “American Maker” highlighted by Dale Dougherty in his 2011 Ted Talk, is symptomatic of the problems associated with American exceptionalism, in that it is “grounded in gendered, white, middle-class cultural practices.” Not only do Vossoughi, Hooper, and Escude critique maker education as it is currently practiced, they also offer proposed solutions for “equity-oriented design” of maker experiences which include, “critical analyses or educational injustice, historicized approaches to making as cross-cultural activity, explicit attention to pedagogy, and inquiry into the sociopolitical values and purposes of making.”

### Maker education is for the general public
Maker education is facilitating and supporting STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) in primary and secondary schools, universities and post-graduate schools. In some areas where STEM is not an integrated part of the schools educational program, fab labs, maker spaces and maker education programs, might be the only way into the world of making for the student. This is also the case for individual citizens, but for some time it must be considered for the innovators / early adaptors.

Dpite these Makeder educational prgrams don't have a closed curriculum, they normally are the door to the "making" world for makers. Normally they start their journey with one of thesse programs that gives them the tools to keep researching and making until they realise their projects. So, we could say that Maker educational progarams are useful for makers, if they are specific on a topic for example, but normally they are more focused on kids or students that could become makers.

trends.Name: Internet of Things Infrastructure & Security
trends.Description:
# Internet of Things Infrastructure & Security

## Smart, intelligent and connected
The world is buzzing around the Internet of Things. Everything is becoming smart, intelligent and connected from cups  that make sure you hydrate intelligently, pets , diapers  and even complete smart cities .  With the rise of popularity of microcontrollers like the Arduino, the Maker Movement seems to become an infinite source of creativity. While not all new connected devices will turn out to be useful or relevant in the long term, this IoT trend has started and is already impacting the way we interact with our houses with products like the Amazon Echo  and smart lightbulbs or how we play sports and exercise with one of many of the  fitness trackers.

Also the industry is embracing this trend with applications across the domain of energy to fully optimize the use of your energy grid, health to monitor our wellness, automotive to enable safe self-driving cars and off course smart manufacturing to optimize production. Cities are looking into IoT to optimize transportation, waste management, safety, etc. Juniper  predicts that the number of connected IoT (Internet of Things) devices, sensors and actuators will reach over 46 billion in 2021. 

## Connectivity for IoT
Although more factors drive the Internet of Things, like the advancements in microcontrollers and artificial intelligence, wireless connectivity is one of the enablers of the Internet of Thigs. Wireless protocols range from short range like Bluetooth, Zigbee, Z-Wave and WiFi to long range technologies like satellite communication and Low-Power Wide-Area Network (LPWAN). Short range wireless are often used in home automation or for personal devices. 
Long range wireless technologies like (LPWAN) have existed for quite a while, but only these last year are being discovered by makers with the popularity of  of LoRa  and SigFox . LPWAN has a limited bandwidth and the devices are only allowed to send a limited number of message each day, but they are very power efficient and can sometimes run for a couple of years on batteries. These features make them ideal for sensor networks, for example to measure air quality or track bicycles.  

LoRa, a LPWAN example,  is interesting because it uses an unlicensed radio spectrum, it allows makers to create their own IoT infrastructure with just a Raspberry Pi  without  the need of a paid subscription from a mobile operator. Initiatives like The Things Network  plan to build a global network infrastructure by providing cheap gateways, open-source firmware and encourage and facilitate their community in building applications with tutorials, YouTube videos and code on GitHub.  

This trend has not been overlooked by the telecom industry, several mobile operators are readying their own LoRa network or focussing on NarrowBand  IoT  (NB-IoT) a licenced alternative that for some mobile operators requires just a software update for their existing infrastructure. On the long term 5G, the next standard for mobile wireless communication, also specifically provides solutions for IoT communication. 

## Will it be safe?
As we are entering the era of Internet of Things, we get surrounded by devices that have access to home or company networks. With several recent incidents, like the attack on internet infrastructure company Dyn , it is clear that these devices can pose a threat not only to the integrity of these networks15 but also to critical internet infrastructures. Not many consumers are aware of these vulnerabilities as they buy their new television, smart light bulb, door lock or fitness bracelet. With many different network and communication protocols, suppliers and products are all competing in the same market. At the same time security has been not been highest priority. With possible severe consequences, experts      urge all stakeholders (manufactures, legislators and users) to come up with regulations and enhance the cybersecurity awareness.

trends.Name: Smart Citizen Sensor Networks
trends.Description: # Smart Citizen Sensor Networks A Smart Citizen Sensor Network is an environmental sensing network most often operating in the public domain. This means that the sensors and their data are connected to each other and they come from citizen sources. Nowadays, citizens use sensing technologies daily, like GPS, videos, etc. combined with the web 2.0 technologies, like social network platforms, P2P computing, etc., so they can participate actively in the network as sensors of the issue they need to gather information and improve. As René Post, from Waag Society says about it on the Making Sense project website (http://making-sense.eu/covey-design-smart-citizens-sensor-networks/), "in order to build successful sensor-networks around a certain environmental issue, we need to combine the elements of (1) concern, awareness, and (2) frustration due to lack of data to start the project. But, in order to keep citizens involved, it might be a good idea to present people not just with numbers, but (3) compile these numbers into actionable information." The main purpose of these networks is to generate participatory processes of people in the cities. These participatory processes normally tackle an environmental issue that citizens want to improve connecting data, people and knowledge. ## Creating a Smart Citizen Network with Smart Citizens Kit and Making Sense project Smart Citizen is a platform to generate participatory processes of people in the cities. Connecting data, people and knowledge, the objective of the platform is to serve as a node for building productive and open indicators, and distributed tools, and thereafter the collective construction of the city for its own inhabitants. The Smart Citizen project is based on geolocation, the Internet and free hardware and software for data collection and sharing. It connects people with their environment and their city to create more effective and optimized relationships between resources, technology, communities, services and events in the urban environment. The Smart Citizen platform is a full set of of tools waiting from you to start using them: register to the platform, check the API, download the Android app, get a Kit or contribute to the open-source project. The Smart Citizen Kit is a piece of hardware comprised of a sensor and a data-processing board, a battery and an enclousure. The first board carries sensors that measure air composition (CO and NO2), temperature, humidity, light intensity and sound levels. Once it’s set up, the device will stream data measured by the sensors over Wi-Fi using the FCC-certified, wireless module on the data-processing board. The device’s low power consumption allows for placing it on balconies and windowsills. Power to the device can be provided by a solar panel and/or battery. The Kit is not another black box, it is compatible with Arduino and all the design files are open-source (schematics and firmware). For more detailed hardware specifications visit https://docs.smartcitizen.me/#/start/hardware The project is born within Fab Lab Barcelona at the Institute for Advanced Architecture of Catalonia, both focused centers on the impact of new technologies at different scales of human habitat, from the bits to geography. It also got founded thanks to lovely bakers on Kickstarter (2013) and Goteo (2012). Making Sense is a European funded project that will run for two years between 2015 and 2017. The aim is to explore how open source software, open source hardware, digital maker practices and open design can be effectively used by local communities to fabricate their own sensing tools, make sense of their environments and address pressing environmental problems in air, water, soil and sound pollution. The project will tackle that issues using three strategies. First of all, using open source technologies that gather environmental data with communities across Europe, they will be co-creating sensors & devices that use the Smart Citizen platform to capture environmental data. They will also enable and design platforms for collective sensemaking: testing tools and methodologies for making sense of data in pilots in Amsterdam, Barcelona and Prishtina, and raising awareness of social and environmental issues. The project will also take action by moving on a trajectory from awareness to positive change: with the pilot learnings they will develop the Making Sense toolkit – a manual to organise citizen sensing campaigns for positive social change. And a Minimum Viable Open Manifesto to provide other projects and their communities with our own insights to better devise citizen engagement strategies and sustainable action plans. The process is currently open and ongoing and it accepts all contributions from all possible sources to keep on amassing new lessons. These are some lessons on the participatory and community building side of Making Sense, mainly harvested and developed from the activities and debates that took place in the past year: A MINIMUM VIABLE OPEN MANIFESTO [Part 1](http://making-sense.eu/towards-minimum-viable-open-manifesto-1) [Part 2](http://making-sense.eu/towards-minimum-viable-open-manifesto-2) [Part 3](http://making-sense.eu/towards-minimum-viable-open-manifesto-3)

trends.Name: Biofabrication & Smart materials
trends.Description: # Biofabrication and smart materials Materials are developing even faster than the machines for digital manufacturing. Material science is not a new trend, but in the near past, a lot of new material have reached the market for small 3D printers. This progress is presumed to be led by the wide distribution of small and affordable printers in every school and lab around the world. This is only expecting to grow faster. Here is a good overview of the normal materials for [FDM printing](https://all3dp.com/best-3d-printer-filament-types-pla-abs-pet-exotic-wood-metal/). Biofabriaction is one of the innovations in new 3D printing techniques and materials that could potentially have a big impact on the medical world. In labs around the world researchers are also working it. ## Biofabrication Biofabrication is the automatic combination and assembly of cells, biochemical or other scaffolding structures to produce tissues (in 2D) or organs (in 3D). This field is the natural evolution of tissue engineering research with cells and stem cells, which is now going toward 3 dimensions and full automation of the process. This field is very active in term of research and the first clinical implementation for bladder fabrication is already available. The time horizon for many more application is 2-10 years. ## Lifetime extension and quality enhancement Biofabrication brings the opportunity to create customized human spare parts, answering a huge need for organ transplant as well as making the medication need after transplant irrelevant as the organs are made fully biocompatible using the patient own cells. Anyone in the general public, who need an organ spare part, will likely be able to "order it" and have it produced from a "Bioprinter". In short the opportunity is lifetime extension and life quality enhancement. It also brings the possibility to “upgrade” itself with better body parts. Biofabrication evolution is likely to meet with biomechatronic science and create a new field of cybernetic organism (cyborg) and biological- computer interfaces such as Neuralink . When engineering humans, ethical question come into consideration, as soon as the possibility for body enhancement will be available to many, there will certainly be regulation by countries that will define what can be done or not. Also the very regulated processes in the field of medicine will certainly create quite some delay between the technology ready for use and the wide adoption of the technology to the masses. Existing biotechnology companies might find a lot of inspiration by this trend and by using their existing experience will be able to innovate in the field. New biotech companies will have the opportunities to innovate in the field with minimum investment needed. It is also a field that will most likely not be affected by any sort of financial crisis, with a very strong value proposition. The equipment needed to start biofabrication is becoming cheap and accessible to all. Makers are already practicing what is called Biohacking (biofabrication by makers), by doing so biohackers might be the one to create the first biotechnologies company on the market with concrete application of biofabrication. ## 4D printing and smart materials Another concept that is related to smart materials trend is 4D printing: 3D printed structures that can change to a “pre-programmed” shape by some kind of external change in the environment. This is possible with “smart materials”. These materials can be effected by either current, temperature, water or other chemical impact. The term also refers to self-assembly of several parts into one part printed in multi-material impacted by e.g. a shake to transform it-self into a new shape. So either the material or each part of the assembly can be “programmed” to act (bend, change size etc.) in a certain way, transforming into a new geometry. 4D printing is a relative new concept, and have so far found very few actual applications. The potential is unpredictable, and MIT have a self-Assembly Lab dedicated to this with Skylar Tibbits talking about a self-assembly world. For instance, an idea is that valves in flow systems can close and open at specific temperatures and underground pipes can repair them self by expanding and closing holes, cracks etc. when exposed to water or the whole system of pipes can adapt to an increased demand. Another creative thought is that buildings in the future with smart materials will change shape or function by water and heat to in order to increase comfort inside. Materials for a regular FDM printer could soon be ￼available to makers and other tinkerers. ￼It's hard to tell what real applications there will be for 4D printing but the researchers in Centre of Excellence for Electromaterials Science , Australia, is currently working on a hand for robotic prosthetics. The hand is made with 3d printed smart materials that will respond to impulses from the brain via an interfaces on the users muscles.

trends.Name: Virtual Currencies & Blockchain
trends.Description: # Virtual Currencies & Blockchain A virtual currency is digital money that is not issued by a bank or a public authority, but which is accepted as mean of electronic payment. Historically virtual currencies were issued and used within the limit of a specific virtual community but the success of cryptocurrencies like bitcoins (seen as a safe asset) made such currencies real alternative to classical currencies. Cryptocurrencies are powered by the blockchain technology which makes them reliable and trustworthy. The virtual currency trend is now quickly growing (thanks to the blockchain technology powering it) into more than just a currency but into a trust platform for exchanging value where the virtual currency comes fully embedded within the platform ( like Ether for Ethereum ). The time horizon is soon (0-2 years) for early adopters but will certainly hit mainstream later (2-5 years). ## A complete change in trade The blockchain will provide a platform for exchange of value and will allow automating most services doing this today. Bitcoin was running on blockchain technology, but was (simply put) just a database listing who owns what amount of bitcoins. Blockchain technology is now evolving and powering, not only a database (to keep track of ownership of the cryptocurrency), but it can execute programmed instruction in a decentralized way. This makes it a decentralized computer that can be trusted to run specific programs (and you can trust the programs will not be tempered with). This allows creating smart contracts which can replace the need for having traditional contracts, as the contract itself is the execution of this program. The smart contract effects the logic of execution of the contract clauses. This automation, with the help of the internet of things, will bring the “middle man” cost in the service industry to be nearly null. This will enable new business models for application that would have otherwise not been profitable. For example a E-lock connected to the blockchain could allow you to rent your bike. This is a quite disrupting trend as it has the potential to totally revolutionize the world of finance governing at the moment. But it is also a huge opportunity to create more value and change society as we know it. ## Driven by the financial sector The financial sector is aware that such trend could disrupt the established system quite seriously; therefore there is currently important investment into Fintech (Finance technology) to be sure to be part of the disruption. A technology is just a tool and is very dependent on the use made from it, so such investment from the financial sector could be a mean to control and delay adoption. Regulation in the area will also play an important role to adoption. ## New ecosystem for maker sustainability The potential of blockchain technology and virtual currencies for Makers an opportunity to operate and exchange value within a virtual community. This could be a key element of creating an ecosystem for maker sustainability. An ecosystem that makes it easy for each maker contributing to a certain project (open source or not), not knowing if it will ever commercialise, to get not only the credit for the work but also paid. Today reserved to a limited crowd, virtual currencies could become a new money reference and be used by mainstream users (everyone) in the later future. For companies such technology could reduce many cost while bringing trust for value exchange.

trends.Name: Industrial 3D Printing
trends.Description:
# Industrial 3D Printing
Industrial 3D printing is associated with additive manufacturing (AM) for “mass” production of parts more than prototypes for fast innovation.  

In Wohlers Report 2017 the industry growth is documented. Wohlers associates define “industrial systems” as AM systems sold for $5000 or more. In 2015 a negative growth is documented and in 2016 a 4% growth is observed51 This is in strong contrast to the growth within the “desktop 3D printer sales” (systems below $5000) where a growth of 49% was observed in 2016 (75% in 2015 and 87% in 2014). 

However, large investments are made within industrial 3D Printing. For instance, in 2016, General Electrics invested approximately 1.3 billion dollars in two producers of metal printer. This indicates that a growth in the coming years is very likely. Generally, large industries as aviation, maritime, automotive and aerospace is investing more in the process and focus have been on production reliability, certification of products and quality assurance/control. 

## Right now: transformation to production 
The focus in industrial 3D printing right now is on reproducibility and reliability. Several large projects between the 3D industry and e.g. the aviation industry carried out in recent years, have not been about exploring what is possible with the geometric freedom or to optimize a certain component, but instead to feel safe about the machine producing an exact copy each time - without [defects](http://www.rep-air.eu/). 

In 2015 the percentage of revenue from AM going to final part production increased above 50% - and in 2016 more than 60% of AM revenue was for final part production. This shows that prototyping is not the main application of 3D print anymore. Metal AM is one of the main reasons for this shift in balance – and the development is expected to continue.  

Metal 3D printing can be expensive compared to what is expected from conventional manufacturing. This is partly due to a lot of manual processes before and after the fabrication. In the nearby future large 3D print services will restructure their facilities in order to get more automated processes. A large metal 3D print production facility opened in 2016 in Germany and more in Europe is expected. 

More and more Industrial 3D Printing “factories” are constructed. For instance, Siemens is mass producing gas [turbines](https://www.siemens.com/innovation/en/home/pictures-of-the-future/industry-and-automation/additive-manufacturing-3d-spare-parts-gas-turbines.html), Michelin is mass producing tire [moulds](http://www.tirebusiness.com/article/20170112/NEWS/170119986/michelin-3d-printing-jv-to-aid-mold-design) and FIT additive manufacturing group recently opened the FIT factory acting as a AM production sub-supplier56.  

A few metal printers in the 100.000 dollars range currently exists, and rapid developments are made to further decrease the price of both machines and consumables. 

## New complications for manufacturing
When 3D printing is disrupting manufacturing industry and is starting to produce actual components (e.g. vital parts for a jet motor for passenger aircrafts) and  the technology completely relies on digital files being converted and transferred from one computer to another through company networks, this opens up to the risk of a digital file being hacked. A hack in the CAD-drawing that changes the finished part with an internal defect. And if this defect is not visible with a simple visual inspection, it can lead to damage over time or when the component is heavily stressed. Researchers did this to show that the new age of manufacturing is vulnerable and the digital infrastructure is critical and [underestimated](http://www.techrepublic.com/article/3d-printing-hack-researchers-crash-drone-with-sabotaged-propeller/). One could argue, that digital manufacturing is not new, with programmed CNC machines, but 3D- printing gives new geometrical opportunities and thereby also vulnerabilities.  

Standardization and certification of 3D printed parts has been a major barrier for a wider use of industrial 3D Printing. However, a number of standards are now developed (e.g. [ASTM F2924](https://www.astm.org/Standards/F2924.htm)) and certification organizations are developing [certification-procedures](http://www.lr.org/en/services/additive-manufacturing/additive-manufacturing-guidance-notes.aspx). 

## From a consumers perspective
In short term, the normal consumer will not feel much effect of the evolving technology. But in niche markets several end-user products is at the plateau of production like high-end HIFI equipment, high-end cycling equipment and glasses. All of these products take advantages of the complex design that 3D print makes possible, thus allowing more advanced products to end user markets than before.  At the same time, a lot of people might have already been flying in an Airbus with some of its vital [components](http://www.engineering.com/AdvancedManufacturing/ArticleID/11948/First-Jet-Engines-with-3D-Printed-Nozzles-Delivered-to-Airbus.aspx) fabricated with 3D print.

trends.Name: Cloud Computing
trends.Description:
# Cloud Computing
Ask someone on the street about a product of Microsoft and they will probably mention Windows or Office. Ask that same person about Amazon and they will probably say it’s an online bookstore or retailer. Not many people will tell you about Microsoft Azure or Amazon Web Services (AWS), even though these are the fastest growing products for both companies. Although not new, the concept of cloud computing is not easily grasped for people outside the ICT business, even though almost all of us are probably using it on a daily basis. 
IBM, an early innovator in cloud computing , describes it on their [website](https://www.ibm.com/cloud-computing/learn-more/what-is-cloud-computing/) as follows “Cloud computing, often referred to as simply “the cloud,” is the delivery of on-demand computing resources — everything from applications to data centres — over the internet on a pay-for-use basis.”    

## Location, Location, Location
Generally clouds are defined by what is in it and where it is located. To start with the last part, 
there are three kinds of clouds: 
* A *public cloud* is a cloud solutions provide by a public company. Your application or data is hosted somewhere else and they will make sure that the hardware and applications will be stay up and running. Especially when you are not sure how many computing resources you will need in the future and it can fluctuate very quickly, the public cloud provides flexibility. 
* In a *private cloud* the end user also is relieved of some of most of the maintenance tasks, but this time the cloud itself is hosted by their own organisation on premises.  Especially for companies working with private or sensitive data. A private cloud must tackle a concern of privacy of the cloud.
* A *hybrid cloud* is a combination of public and private cloud. Private data can still be stored in a private cloud, where non sensitive data and applications can move between a private and public cloud, depending on the need for resources. 

According to [Right Scale](http://www.rightscale.com/blog/cloud-industry-insights/cloud-computing-trends-2017-state-cloud-survey), currently the hybrid cloud is still the most popular cloud option, but the adoption of the public is expected to grow faster. A North Bridge survey  showed that the spending on public cloud and is expected to account for 50% of all hardware, software and outsourcing services.   

## Inside the cloud
So what is actually running inside a cloud? One of the most basic cloud services provides the user with hardware that they can completely manage themselves. They can install the operating system and the applications, the only thing that is provided is an infrastructure in the cloud. That is why this is called Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS). If you don’t want to manage the platform but want to run your own applications, cloud providers will offer you a Platform as a Service (PaaS). Sometimes even the software itself is already provided, these are Software as a Service (SaaS) cloud services. 

## Making it in the cloud
Gmail, Google Docs, Office 365 are among some of the more well-known and popular SaaS solutions, but many of the online services is used by developers and makers to share code, collaborate like GitHub and Slack but also to design or create like [Canva](https://about.canva.com/), etc. are all Software as a Service. They are popular among makers and developers as they often provide free use for small teams and projects or support open source initiatives. Many makers collaborating in online teams are living and making in the cloud. And you can leave it to the makers to maintain a list of free cloud offerings for developers.  

The flexibility of cloud computing is often the reason why start-ups are interested in cloud technologies. All big cloud  platforms support start-ups with attractive deals, hoping they will turn out to be the ‘next big thing’. At the same time the cloud services provide more and more additional services like data analytics, video streaming or machine learning. Services that were traditionally only available for large tech companies are now available for makers and start-ups to experiment with new concepts and products. Alexa Voice Service (AVS)   is recent example by Amazon which allows companies and makers to integrate the Natural Voice technology that powers the Amazon Echo in their own products. At GitHub  Amazon shares an example how to run  AVS on your own Raspberry Pi.

trends.Name: All-in-one maker machines
trends.Description: # All-in-one maker machines The “All-in-one maker machines” are a combination of different digital fabrication tools in one machine. Normally that device combine a 3D printer, a CNC milling machine and a laser cutter. CNC milling machines and 3D printers share the same structure: their robotic head moves in the three axes X, Y and Z. This is guided by a microcontroller, an Arduino, or any other computerized mechanical system. Despite these tools share a similar structure and technology, their technique of making is different. 3D printers use an "additive manufacturing technique, which means they add material layer by layer to make a piece. On the other hand, CNC milling machines and laser cutters use a subtractive technique: from a piece of material they cut or scratch off the extra material to make the final piece. That makes it possible to have a three axis structure with a changeable head tool and switch between one tool or technique an another. In an industrial level, this have been possible for years now and there are machines with even 200 different interchangeable tool. On the final consumer level, this is a new trend and it's hard to find an all-in-one maker machine that has a nice quality and it's low-cost. ## All-in-one in the market As commented before, multipurpose machines are common in the industry but in a los-cost level the available range of devices I limited. Most of them are in a price range starting from 500€, in kickstarter projects for example, to 3500€, for the most advanced like the ones that can even print with biological materials. The table below shows the best all-in-one maker machines in 2017 compiled by the by the 3D printing specialist website [all3dp.com](http://www.all3dp.com). ## All that glitters is not gold After talking with experienced makers, the thread or downside of these kind of machines is that they are not that precise. That means that a “traditional” 3D printer, laser cutter or CNC milling machine can achieve neater final results, for instance: clean cuts, high definition printings or objects, etc. That makes high quality final products ready to sell. On the other hand, the all-in-one maker machines offers three, four or five different tools or techniques, but, as they are a new trend still under development, the quality of the combined tools is not as high as the quality of the “traditional” separated tools. That makes the all-in-one maker machines perfect for prototyping, for students or amateur projects, but not that good to make a final product ready for the market. ## All-in-one machines for makers As stated, all-in-one machines can be useful for makers but probably not in all the cases. These machines are good for prototyping and also for maker educational programs in primary and secondary schools, universities and post-graduate schools. They can be useful for individual citizens and early adopters that want to test and support this new technology. But at the final consumer level, these kind of devices are still expensive and not producing high quality products to sell in the market. So it we can tell that they will be really valuable for makers in some years, when the technology and the options are more developed.

trends.Name: Robotics and robot arms
trends.Description:
# Robotics and robot arms Robots, robot arm and robotics comes in many shapes and sizes. Applications range from pick and place in production facilities over toys to domestic tasks. Some are very simple in shape and function and in recent years, even advanced robot arms with several axis (bends or rotation) has become very easy to install with motion recordings. Robots have been around for many years and in the past few years development pace have increased a lot together with Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (AI). Author of the book, [Rise of the robots](https://www.amazon.com/Rise-Robots-Technology-Threat-Jobless/dp/0465097537), Martin Ford, predicts that, in Amerika only, millions of low wage jobs is replaced by robots and especially the fast food industry will be soon to implement the new technology, where robots will not only deliver the food but also make it. ## Helping out or overtaking There is no doubt about that robots is changing the way factories of the future works, but could it also change the way we live our lives. We already see many automated processes in our home, freeing time for us to spend otherwise. In recent year robots has also entered as a part of the educational programme in Europe alongside with entrepreneurships, innovation and creativity. The robotics is useful as a tool to promote a different and experimental approach in learning even for young kids. Mind controlled (neurally) robotics arms attached to a person’s amputated limb as a prosthetic – a bionic arm – is fairly new and not a finished product yet, but a handful of groups in U.S and Europa have come a long way. In the field of bionics arms, the development is closely followed in the Maker movement as well with among other projects the open source Open bionics. On the other hand, some predicts a dark future for humans when robots is developed to fulfil many of our existing jobs and outperform us. This is most likely to affect jobs like drivers, accountants, labours, and waiters. Also at risk is [construction workers](http://www.construction-robotics.com/), [carers](http://medicalfuturist.com/robotics-healthcare/) and [soldiers](http://www.bostondynamics.com/). This could result in a lot of spare time for people in the future, but that might not be so fantastic according to Professor [Moshe Vardi](https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2016-02/ru-wmc021016.php) and computer scientist [Jürgen Schmidhuber](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/apr/18/robot-man-artificial-intelligence-computer-milky-way). ## Makers make professional robot arms Robotic arms is, like any other technology, getting smart and cheaper by each day. This leads to robots handling tasks that are more advanced, but also smaller and simpler tasks - since buying the robot arm and installing it, is cheap and easy. It has become easy by programming it with e.g. motion recording (handhold teaching), easy-of-use software with 3D visualisation and self-learning / AI. Some projects making this happen comes from [maker communities](http://makezine.com/2015/09/18/robot-arms-you-can-buy-soon/) and start-ups.
Some of the robotic machines coming from the maker communities solves very simple tasks like alarming when mail is delivered and is mostly for fun etc. but others is perfected to be very precise, stabile and ease of use and at the same time is capable of working as a [multipurpose machine](http://makerarm.com/). Other makers collaborate and aim high in making an [open source self-driving car](https://www.udacity.com/self-driving-car). ## Domestic robots From a consumer’s perspective by now, robotics have only affected the price on consumer goods, making them cheaper and in some places replaced several workers in the nearby factory. In the UK, [reports](https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2016-02/ru-wmc021016.php) state that by 2035 1/10 jobs is replaced by [robots](https://www.adzuna.co.uk/blog/2017/01/27/drivers-and-receptionists-are-most-at-risk-from-losing-their-jobs-to-automation/) and in 2050 about 50%. The thought of having a robot in your home as a servant might not be appealing to everyone, but slowly robots will be become a part of our everyday lives. Already people use robot lawn mowers, vacuum cleaners, gutter cleaner, pool cleaners and coffee machines - that can serve you a drink that used to require a “skilled” barista. When technology that only used to be a part of a production facility finds more awareness in our minds and application in homes, it becomes more natural for us to interact with it. By now, it is not uncommon as a toy for children like a programmable teddy bear or an assembly kit with computer, actuators and sensors etc. like Lego Mindstorms among others (The online shop [www.robotshop.com](http://www.robotshop.com) has 117 products in the category Robot Toys.) Fully self-driving or semi driving ([driver assistance systems](https://www.lifewire.com/advanced-driver-assistance-systems-534859)) cars, [bar mixing drinks](http://www.moley.com/) (but hey, all it does is pouring the liquids in the glass!) is already a reality and the future could easily bring fully [robotic kitchen help](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xYA2d35e-w8). ## Productions = Robot arms There is no doubt that robots are going to have a huge impact already in the production facilities all over the world. Right now in Europe, we typically see that robots are making insourcing feasible again. While, for many years the “easy” way to gain profit in a society demanding cheaper products, was to outsource manufacturing to low wage countries around the world, it is now time for insourcing (except for Germany). Robots are an essential part of Industry 4.0 to ensure an intelligent, reliable but flexible production based on increased automatization and sophisticated robots.[more](https://www.roboticsbusinessreview.com/manufacturing/industry_4-0_robotics_presents_a_golden_opportunity/) In enterprises, robots and humans will likely be working together by side in within a few years, opposed to now a day, where the robot is safely shielded of in a cage, and the process is stopped when a human is passing into the working area. This is a challenge for certification/standardisation bodies focusing on safety together with the developers of the robot arms. Many SME’s right now see the benefits in robot taking over the dull monotone work but it’s still a challenge economically or [practically](http://www.gereports.com/post/107898198705/rethink-robotics-is-freeing-next-gen-robots-from/). The enabler is robots getting smarter and [easier to install](https://www.universal-robots.com/products/ur-robot-benefits/), so production can keep running.

trends.Name: IPR for makers
trends.Description: # IPR for makers Intellectual property rights for makers, describes the problematic linked to ownership of intellectual property in a world where digitization becomes the norm. In a world where bits are the new atoms industries getting digitized will encounter the exact same issues that the music industry had to face. It will become increasingly difficult to small players to reach sustainability when the maker of a design looses any type of control the second the design is shared. No matter if the maker wants to allow free access or sale his IP without a platform to manage Intellectual property makers are struggling to stay in control. This also reveals a need for makers to be sustainable to move from the hobby level to a professional one. Time horizon for technologies to emerge in this field is a bout [2 years](http://www.insidecounsel.com/2016/02/09/lets-look-closer-at-3d-printing-and-ip-issues?slreturn=1493415811). The opportunity of using such platform to manage IPR is the possibility to become a sustainable business by selling IP rights and reaching many using a trusted environment. For example a blockchain powered Data right management platform could allow to keep full traceability of IPR for makers while enabling new business models to emerge. The thread for makers and all industries disrupted by digitization is the huge loss of revenues or potential revenues linked to IP theft. Enterprises are schedule to suffer huge lost, if they do not embrace digitization and the technologies that can give an edge in protecting their IPR.

Scores.Title: Category
Scores.Description: An additive manufacturing method for fabricating tangiable products in 3 dimensions in various materials. If not stated otherwise, the part is build up layer by layer for each technology.

Scores.Title: SubCategory
Scores.Description:
Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) 
 - Commonly known as FDM, which is actually a Stratasys' trademark.
The material in shape of a strand, called filament, is extruded by a heated head typically controlled in y and x direction. This is by far the most well-known 3D-print technology. Surface finish, strength, precision etc. vary a depending on the machine quality and the users ability to adjust and replace components.
Synonyms: Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM), Plastic Jet Printing (PJP)

radarinput.Examples: Makerbot - Replicator 5th Gen [http://store.makerbot.com/replicator], UP Plus [https://www.up3d.com/], Metal [https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/produce-the-mini-metal-maker#/],BigRep - One [https://bigrep.com/bigrep-one/], Stratasys - Fortus [http://www.stratasys.com], Dimension [http://www.stratasys.com], uPrint and Mojo [http://www.stratasys.com/3d-printers/technologies/fdm-technology]

radarinput.Description: Binder Jetting is 3D printing with a powder material and liquid bonding agent applied by an inkjet print head. When the print job is done, the excess powder material is removed and reused.

Scores.Title: Category
Scores.Description: An additive manufacturing method for fabricating tangiable products in 3 dimensions in various materials. If not stated otherwise, the part is build up layer by layer for each technology.

Scores.Title: SubCategory
Scores.Description:
Binder Jetting (BJ) 
Powder material (gypsum or plastic) is clued together with a binder extruded through print heads. These printers are often able to print in colours and the mechanism is very simple so they can be opened to any material. Parts are often fragile but can be strengthened with epoxy or similar.

Scores.Title: Category
Scores.Description: An additive manufacturing method for fabricating tangiable products in 3 dimensions in various materials. If not stated otherwise, the part is build up layer by layer for each technology.

Scores.Title: SubCategory
Scores.Description:
Laser Melting (LM)
A fiber laser beam is controlled in Y and X direction by mirrors (scanning). This generates a melt pool (typically of 200 µm), which micro welds fine metal powder fully together, achieving mechanical properties comparable with traditional machined parts.
Synonyms: Selective Laser Melting (SLM), Direct Metal Laser Sintering (DMLS), Laser Cusing

radarinput.Description: The collaboration on owned content is a concept where an owner of a file sets up a free download, but legally owns any change made to the file by users. For the industry this can give acces to a fast and versatile workforce. For a public domain it can let everyone have access to all current as well as future configurations of a file instead of any single person. For the maker it means easy access to high quality models.
